newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish 1997 budget plan to aim at 2.6 pct deficit.
newsitem.headline: Polish 1997 budget plan to aim at 2.6 pct deficit.

text.p: The Polish government will start on Tuesday debating a 1997 budget draft, which aims at a deficit of 2.6 percent of gross domestic product and a real rise in revenues and spending, the government spokeswoman said.

Aleksandra Jakubowska told a news conference the government, which has until the end of October to submit its draft to parliament, was likely to continue discussions at an extra session later in the week.

"As far as I know, the budget deficit has been set at 2.6 percent of GDP...and real revenues are to grow by 8.3 percent, while spending by 8.6 percent," Jakubowska said. This year's budget gap is set at 2.8 percent of GDP.
The government approved in July the deficit target during its debate on the general budget outline.

But it received only last week the detailed finance ministry draft of the bill, and some analysts speculated the final budget bill proposal might assume a bigger shortfall to make room for higher spending in the election year.
Jakubowska also said under the draft the ratio of the budget's revenues to GDP would increase to no more than 27.9 percent from this year's 27.6 percent.
The spending to GDP ratio would fall to 29.5 percent from 30.4 percent this year.

Jakubowska confirmed the government priorities in the budget draft would include real wage increase for public sector workers and pensioners and higher spending for eductation, science, culture, agriculture and construction.
